title: Talking raven sounds human as he calls visitors to a German zoo 'my darling'
text:
A talented raven has learned to mimic the sound of a human and has used it to utter the German phrase for 'my darling'.

Wildlife photographer Lothar Lenz came across the tame raven at a nearby zoo in Eifel, Germany, with an extraordinary talent of listening and repeating phrases.

Mr Lenz decided to record the bird as it utters 'mein schätzchen', translated in English as 'my darling', with pinpoint pronunciation.

In the footage, the jet-black bird can be seen standing in a grassy area as it opens its beak wide.

Sure enough it can then be heard saying 'mein schätzchen' with a flick of its tongue.

It repeats it for a second time before turning its head to the side inquisitively and strolling off toward the undergrowth.

Wildlife photographer Lothar Lenz came across the tame raven at a nearby zoo in Eifel, Germany, with an extraordinary talent of listening and repeating phrases

The bird had learnt to say 'mein schätzchen' - with perfect pronunciation - which translates to the affectionate call

The video then cuts to a short time later to the bird once again as it clicks its beak and continues to repeat its charming phrase.

In a series of other mini-clips that follow the bird continues to try and communicate using clicks and squawks as it hops along the ground.

But it always reverts back to its favourite saying.

The raven had previously been treated for a broken wing when it was found and so is friendly around humans.
description: The jet-black bird was spotted at a zoo in Eifel, Germany, by wildlife photographer Lothar Lenz. He filmed it repeatedly saying 'mein schätzchen' which translates to the affectionate phrase.
